channel.title: Comments on: PuSHPress: A PubSubHubbub Plugin For WordPress

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/03/03/pushpress-a-pubsubhubbub-plugin-for-wordpress/#comment-3312">Dan</a>.
There is nothing specifically built it to do this. You can add some logging to the plugin that records all of the out going pings to make sure they are getting sent correctly.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Dan.

There is nothing specifically built it to do this. You can add some logging to the plugin that records all of the out going pings to make sure they are getting sent correctly.

item.title: By: Dan
item.dc:creator: Dan
item.description: Thank you for the reply. How can I verify #1 is correctly occuring?
item.content:encoded: Thank you for the reply. How can I verify #1 is correctly occuring?

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/03/03/pushpress-a-pubsubhubbub-plugin-for-wordpress/#comment-3310">Dan</a>.
Two things that could be going on:
1- making sure that pings are being sent out ok for your other subdomain sites 2- ultimately Google is the one that decides what to do with the ping data, it may be that they only do rapid updates for certain sites, I don't know
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Dan.

Two things that could be going on:

1- making sure that pings are being sent out ok for your other subdomain sites
2- ultimately Google is the one that decides what to do with the ping data, it may be that they only do rapid updates for certain sites, I don’t know

item.title: By: Dan
item.dc:creator: Dan
item.description: I used WPMU to network activate this plugin. When I posted a test post from my main domain blog I saw that Google indexed it very quickly but for my subdomain posts it was not occurring the same way. Is there anything else I need to do?
item.content:encoded: I used WPMU to network activate this plugin. When I posted a test post from my main domain blog I saw that Google indexed it very quickly but for my subdomain posts it was not occurring the same way. Is there anything else I need to do?

item.title: By: Gary
item.dc:creator: Gary
item.description: Will this plugin support Wordpress 3.1? Thanks.

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/03/03/pushpress-a-pubsubhubbub-plugin-for-wordpress/#comment-3306">Marc</a>.
There is nothing in PuSHPress currently to support excluding specific categories, it just watches for publish events and sends the data along. To address something like this right now you'll need to hack the plugin a bit to check for that category that you want to exclude.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Marc.

There is nothing in PuSHPress currently to support excluding specific categories, it just watches for publish events and sends the data along. To address something like this right now you’ll need to hack the plugin a bit to check for that category that you want to exclude.

item.title: By: Marc
item.dc:creator: Marc
item.description:
First of all - awesome plugin, thanks for it.
One Question... I excluded one category from my feed with a global function $query->set('cat','-1')
When I check my /feed everything is fine, posts of this category don't appear. But PuSHPRess works different? When I check my Google Reader, I see these posts... Any idea how to fix this? Thanks :-)
item.content:encoded:
First of all – awesome plugin, thanks for it.

One Question… I excluded one category from my feed with a global function $query->set(‘cat’,’-1′)

When I check my /feed everything is fine, posts of this category don’t appear. But PuSHPRess works different? When I check my Google Reader, I see these posts…
Any idea how to fix this? Thanks ðŸ™‚

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/03/03/pushpress-a-pubsubhubbub-plugin-for-wordpress/#comment-3304">PubCrawl</a>.
The PuSHPress plugin includes a hub, there is no need to manually ping a hub about updates. When you publish a new post in WordPress PuSHPress knows about it, so it can immediately turn around and send out the client pings.
If you are using PuSHPress to add PuSH support to your WP install the only thing you need to do is activate the plugin, it takes care of everything else.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to PubCrawl.

The PuSHPress plugin includes a hub, there is no need to manually ping a hub about updates. When you publish a new post in WordPress PuSHPress knows about it, so it can immediately turn around and send out the client pings.

If you are using PuSHPress to add PuSH support to your WP install the only thing you need to do is activate the plugin, it takes care of everything else.

item.title: By: PubCrawl
item.dc:creator: PubCrawl
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2010/03/03/pushpress-a-pubsubhubbub-plugin-for-wordpress/#comment-3303">Joseph Scott</a>.
Yes, but... I'm not *subscribing*, I'm "ping"ing the hub to publish an update to my blog, per <a href="http://pubsubhubbub.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/pubsubhubbub-core-0.3.html#anchor9" rel="nofollow">http://pubsubhubbub.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/pubsubhubbub-core-0.3.html#anchor9</a>. The way I read the spec is that to avoid polling (polling sucks, eh?) you notify the hub of new content, which then is supposed to be queued for distribution?
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Joseph Scott.

Yes, but… I’m not *subscribing*, I’m “ping”ing the hub to publish an update to my blog, per
http://pubsubhubbub.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/pubsubhubbub-core-0.3.html#anchor9. The way I read the spec is that to avoid polling (polling sucks, eh?) you notify the hub of new content, which then is supposed to be queued for distribution?
